This device couples to a standard plastic garden hose quick-connector. It should work with most brands (I've found that these things are actually pretty universal, US design is the same as in in Europe! Major surprise). What does it do? It connects. That's all. You'll have to mod it to make something useful out of it. I'm anxiously awaiting images of people watering their lawn with a Bre or Colbert nozzle. And if you really want to print something that would totally warrant your ultimaker or makerbot investment, why not create a spray nozzle or sprinkler system that exactly waters the shape of your lawn.

There are two versions: one with a cutout for a rubber washer, the other with an integrated (printed) washer.
1 Print.
2 Check fit & with your system.
3 Tinker
4 upload your designs & link to this one There is a solidworks file for the specialists.

A HAT designed to host the battery and electronics from a 2600mah Power bank such as :

http://www.dx.com/p/kinston-universal-usb-output-2600mah-li-ion-portable-external-power-bank-black-366080#.VcT5vJPjeOw

or

http://www.dx.com/p/2600mah-external-battery-mobile-power-bank-blue-lemon-scent-205731#.VcT61JPjeOw

This HAT will block access to the DSI port ... but who cares for now.

1) Open the original power bank (use a guitar pick, not a knife), and remove the electronics.
2) Print the two halves of the HAT or foldable version
3) install the electronic in the top half of the HAT and secure the wiring with hot-glue.
4) assemble or fold the bottom half
3) screw to either the bottom side or the top side or the raspberry pi (B+, A+ or B2) using at least 20mm standoff

For better finish, you can print some clips and use them to secure the two halves, close to the battery cylinder.

Depending on your printer, you may need to add support (interior of cylinder).

This is the Commodore C64 connector plate recreated by me. I have many C64 computers (breadbox type) with holes for switches or buttons. They do not look very good and I wanted to restore them to their almost original look. It is also possible to add holes for SD2IEC, switches or LED's.
Ooops, just saw a problem in this thing. Please redownload.
Created with FreeCAD. Printed with Velleman K8200 (equiped with 0.35 mm nozzle). It must be rotated on X or Y axis by 180° in Repetier Host.

A 2-piece bucket-like mold containing the inner seashell castle.

Wide clamps are to be used for holding the 2 pieces while also serving as a grip. To then be removed, after which the bucket is gently removed 1 piece at a time

3d sculpted castle, mostly by hard surface modeling, as a foundational base that would later cut into the bucket.
After which the now reformed bucket is divided into 2 pices, then the holes in the polygonal mesh would be filled/bridged, and lastly decimation tools to lower the overall raw polycount.

A filament holder for the RepRap Mendel. Clips onto M8 threaded rods; the centres of which are separated by 58.5mm (see image). As the reel is sitting on four bearings, it is free to rotate and can be easily removed when needed.

To use the same configuration as me, you will need:

  • 2x printed mounts
  • 4x 608 bearings
  • 8x M8 nuts
  • 16x internal-toothed lock washers
  • 4x M8 washers with outer diameter greater than 22mm
  • 2x M8 threaded rod cut to a length approximately equal to [width of filament spool]+50mm

Steps

  1. Drill out/file the two upper holes if the M8 rod won't fit

  2. Assemble the rods so on each rod the sequence is:
    lock washer - large washer - lock washer - bearing - lock washer - nut - nut - lock washer - bearing - lock washer - large washer - lock washer

  3. Slide the printed mounts onto the end of each rod

  4. Add a lock washer and nut to the ends of each rod

  5. Adjust the space between the inside of the large washers to be about 2mm wider than your filament spool

  6. Tighten all nuts top lock everything in place

author: SwimmingNaked

description.text:
I wanted an accurate way to see how far from the center of the bed I was printing. So I made a target to print and then mark the bed to see how far off I was.

To use:

Optional. Place a piece of painters tape on the bed to keep the bed clean of pen marks.

  1. Place the targets model on the beds center in your slicing program.

  2. Slice and print the model.

  3. After the print is done mark the bed. (I used a standard sharpie.)

  4. Remove print and measure the X distance and Y distance from the center of your bed. Note these values.

  5. In your slicing program input those values in your offset bed options. (I use Simplify3D see attached photo)

  6. Recenter the target in your slicing program.

  7. Reprint target. It should now print in the very center of your print bed.

  8. Feel satisfied about your newly centered print bed.

Multipurpose mount for Boscam FR632 Diversity Receiver.

Has attachment point for "GoPro" style mount, hole that can be direct threaded with a 1/4-20 screw, and a quick-release shoe for a tripod.

The 1/4-20 hole is a little small so it takes some force to get the screw started, but that way it will be a better fit. You could also try tapping the hole if you prefer.

The tripod quick-release shoe was made for the Sunpak Platinum Plus tripod, but may fit others.

GoPro mount part came from here.

Works with PLA or ABS. Check the instructions tab for printing details.

Update: Added new stl file with proper orientation. The only difference between the two is the orientation of the object.

Model files available here. Lots of export formats to choose from if you want to modify it.

Print with the receiver bottom (face with cable holes) down. The tripod shoe should be at a 45 degree angle to the bed.

Prints without supports.

I recommend a brim to make sure the first layer of the tripod shoe doesn't separate.

Any wall thickness around 1mm and top/bottom thickness over .5mm should be fine. (2-3 shells and 3-4 top/bottom layers)

For my prints I used the following settings:
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Shell thickness: 1.2 mm
Bottom/Top thickness: 0.6 mm
Fill Density: 15%

It works with M3 screw and small spring. It design to go on 20x20 T-slot

This is a dummy servo for those instances, you're building a model, which has to fly one day, but you don't have this size servo's on the shelf
In order to build it, these serve dummy come in handy.

Designed after a GWS Naro servo
Size: 22x11x20 mm ( 0.86 x 0.43 x 0.78 in)

2 part print ( housing: 10% fill, raft + support; arm 50% fill min, raft)

assemble and tweak parts if necessary.

The arm/ rudder horn rotates (by hand off course ;-) in the housing.

Included is de 123D cad file to mod if you need a different size servo

any questions/ remarks: let me know

Didn't do any 3d design for 20 yrs, this is my first attempt to get back in ;-)

2 part print:
housing: 10% fill, raft + support (1,7 m. filament, 32 min)
arm 50% fill min, raft (0,5 m filament, 10 min)

I print on a simple XYZprinting Da Vinci Junior 1.0 and it works!
without tuning, just clean up the raft and supports!

Have fun!

A 3'' diameter sphere composed out of 12 of the exact same parts. Print them in multiple colors or all the same. Designed to visualize possible colors.

A rhombic dodecahedron was projected onto a sphere to create the shape. Tabs and inserts were added so the pieces could fit together without gluing.

To assemble just snap the pieces together. Make sure they are very clean and all support material is removed. Once they are together try no to take them apart as they will not hold together as well. To insert the final piece you may need to pry open with a screwdriver in order for it to fit.

If any issues arise or if you want something similar but more or less pieces let me know and I would be happy to help.

title: "Control my Cap" Mortar Board LED Holder

description.text: These are the 3D printed parts for holding the LED Board on my graduation mortar board, along with the light diffuser. This design has been printed and tested successfully on a MakerBot Replicator Dual, using PLA. This was specifically created as a part of my "Control my Cap" project. You can learn more about it here: http://www.jeremyblum.com/portfolio/control-my-cap/

Print the cap base, and four of the cap clips. You will also need some additional hardware:
  • Camera Flash Diffuser (http://www.amazon.com/Gary-Fong-INVDOM-Lightsphere-Replacement/dp/B00119MWPK/)
  • 8 10mm M3 Socket Cap bolts (McMaster Part: 91292A113)
  • 12 M3 nuts (McMaster Part: 90592A009)
  • 4 31mm Threaded M3 Male-Female Hex Standoffs (McMAster Part: 98952A122)

title: Rotary Switch with magnet actuating reed switches for audio sources
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an idea I've had for an audio input selector based on a magnet actuating reed switches, there will be 4 stereo inputs going to one stereo pair. The reasoning behind this is that every mechanical audio switch gets crackly over time, the switch on my old Naim pre-amp is very worn and needs replacing. I like the idea of reed switches as they can theoretically last forever when switching low voltages and being actuated with a permanent magnet means that no power is required. I am offering this design in the hope that others will offer their ideas as I have had a mental block as to where to go with it. Thanks in advance folks...
I haven't made it yet!

comments.text:
I think your approach is ok but could be better.
If you take apart rotary switches you would find that they are mostly flat disks that use a ball bearing with a leaf spring that allows for the switch to lock into a set position. This would be the way to go. What you have here I think would cause issues with rotating after some time.
I will try to make a version that will work. It will take a bit of time as I have a few projects I need to finish first.

author: Max_Skies

title: Raspberry Pi + Adafruit LCD Keypad Pi-Plate Wrist Mount

description.text: This is case for the Raspberry Pi plus the Adafruit LCD+Keypad Pi Plate (http://www.adafruit.com/products/1115). It comfortably holds and protects both while leaving all the port accessible. Most importantly, it snaps onto a bracelet that allows you to strap your raspberry pi to your wrist! I used this for my "Control My Cap" Project, wherein a web-connected Raspberry Pi on my wrist was used to control a light-up display on my graduation mortar board. You can learn more here: http://www.jeremyblum.com/portfolio/control-my-cap/

Print out the top and bottom parts of the Pi case, as well as the bracelet.  The bracelet will need to be printed with support. Install the pi in the bottom of the case, and mount the LCD plate on top. Snap the top of the case on. Then, snap the bracelet in to the bottom clips.  I recommend securing it with a few dabs of super glue since the fit is not very tight. The channel on the bottom can be used for routing the power micro USB cable so it can run up your arm along with the other USB cables that you might choose to plug in.

Sarychev Peak constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.1 million polygons). Sarychev is a stratovolcano that covers most of Matua Island which is in the Kuril Islands of Russia. This map was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.

No supports, 5% infill (just to keep the back straight. I do like to use a brim just to be safe.

you can scale up if needed, but I wouldn't scale down very far, else the disc will be too thin.

author: totosolat

description.text:
Snake Charger - Tesla Motors.

Make and control your own Tesla Snake Charger.
Print how many "body" pieces you want to make a big snake.
Articulated arm toy.

Original Tesla snake charger video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zsAoMkm_DEw

Easy to print and mount.
And it is funny... O_o

You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

All you need:

  • 3x wire (any strong and flexible wire).
  • 1x plastic stick (optional, like a 5/16 inch hot glue stick).

You can fix more "wires" in others parts of the snake body,
to create multiple stage control on the arm,
like you see in the video.

In the video you can count at least:

  • 5 motors and drivers for control.
  • 2 separate segments in the arm.
  • 16 body parts + tip and base.

How mount:

  • Join all body pieces.
  • Put the head in the top.
  • Put the tail in the bottom.
  • Pass the plastic stick for the central hole in all pieces(optional).
  • Pass the 3 wires for the lateral holes in all pieces.
  • Fix the wires in the head.
  • Pass the wires for the tail channels
  • Fix the tail in a table.
  • Well done.

Use pegs to fix the cables and hold the snake position.

description.text:
These mounts can be expensive and they seem to get lost very easily, so… another request from my IT dept to design a 3D printable version. Lots on Thingiverse, but i like a challenge!
Fits into a standard Flash Shoe mount, with Ninjaflex clamp ring mount and collar to isolate the mic from any vibration (tan coloured parts). All part are either thread or slot together - no glue should be needed.
All parts print without supports at 0.2mm (or higher for threaded parts).
Print the Flash shoe mount with 100% infill for strength.
The mic clamp is joined at the hinge by a metal 'pin' (see parts photo) i discovered a cut down large paper clip worked great (1.75mm dia).

Print in a strong filament of your choice.
I used Faberdashery Classic Black
http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/classic-black/
and Caramel Ninjaflex http://www.fennerdrives.com/%20ninjaflex3dprinting/_/3d//.

NOTE:
This mount hasn't been fully tested, i will post updates if parts design evolve.

Enjoy!

Four 8" ruler-like tool displaying .5", 1", 1.5", and 2" conic fillets from rho=.95 concave to rho=.95 convex.

Rho=0 (flat/chamfer) at the center and rho=.5 (parabolic) at the two .5 markers. The .4 markers have an "R" above them to indicate the location of constant radius (standard fillet) which fall at rho=~.42

Ruler is marked by the dividing wall at rho = 0 (center), and with tick marks at rho = .1, .2, .25, .3, .4, .5, .6, .7, .75, .8, .9 for both concave and convex fillets.

This is a super useful tool for learning surface modeling concepts. By looking at how light reflects off the ruler, you can see how a standard fillet provides poor surface continuity compared to a rho=.75 conic, and why that might be used instead. Scaling the model can show how larger conic fillets with a higher rho value can replace a smaller fillet for a better surface finish (i.e. using a 1" rho=.75 conic in place of a .5" standard fillet).
--
Rev C:
-Deeper/larger engravings for tick marks
-Added fillets to smooth sharp edges

Rev B:
-rho=.5 is a parabola, not a radius as it was in Rev A. rho~=.42 is where the radius falls.
-Added an "R" above rho=.4 marks to indicate it is a radius

I came across a snag with my external camera flash when designing the Rotobooth (my flickr photobooth). The flash, a Canon 430ex, does not have a DC power option (the ability to plug into an external power source). This would require the four AA batteries to be swapped out approximately every 200 photos.
As a work around, I cut a wooden dowel to size to make two false batteries to charge the capacitor. Voltage was easy to determine â€“ 4 Ã— 1.5 Volt batteries = 6VDC. Next I connected a bench power supply to watch the current draw (amperage). This determines how quickly the flash will charge.

I have not used high current on these batteries yet, so you may need a regulator before running the leads (don\'t melt it into you battery compartment)! Thanks Corey.
Also, I used screws on either side of the batteries to affix the leads and glued some copper mesh to maximize surface area of the conductors.

description.text:
This is a simple redesign of the original Hephestos Z Axis, in particular the two X axis parts.

  • The parts now support a 8mm threaded rod, including a fitting for the nut.
  • On the inside there was a small lip added on the bottom preventing the bearings from falling out over time.

Everything else is default for the Hephestos.

comments.text: the thing with 8 mm rods is that they are not really strait and usually cause bad resolution and left to right giggle seeing how much stronger compared to 5 mm rods that flex and fallow the 8mm smooth rods long them which are usually a lot straighter  . Just a tip ! I tried and went bk to 5mm.
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: thanks for the tip. I switched over to 8mm rods due to resonances caused by the original 5mm rods. I already have a I3 running with 8mm rods, the above one is the second one I build. I had the problem of the rods not being perfectly strait on my printrbot. Now I have the rods machined by a friend of mine, so they are quite strait ;-) But I will keep that in mind when calibrating it. Thanks!

comments.text: Well im sure properly made rods would be much better then the china junk we can find easily here. my first build was with those and then I switch to 5mm, well they are 3/16 and I also had resonation problems because the prusa calculator doesn't have the calculations for the 3/16 and I was using the 5mm calculation, but with little tweaking I nailed the right magic number. BTW it was not being a nitpicker was just sharing with you my experience with 8mm rods.

description.text: This case fits all of your drawing essentials into one pack for when you want to get artsy on the go.

Printing:

  1. Print the two outer pieces and the bolt in normal PLA or other hard material.
  2. Print the two inner pieces in Ninjaflex or other soft material. These have to be printed in a soft material because of the overhangs that hold the pencils in on the top piece. You would not be able to get pencils in or out if they were hard.

Assembly:

  1. Put the inner pieces in their respective outer pieces (they should not need glue to stay in, but you can put some in if you really want to).
  2. Put your drawing essentials in the slots and compartments (you can use my setup as a guide, but it doesn't have to be exactly the same).
  3. Put the top and bottom pieces together, with the rod on the top piece going through the non-threaded hole on the bottom piece.
  4. Put the bolt in from the top and tighten until it feels secure.

safe storage for counting chambers (eg. Fuchs-Rosenthal, Neubauer hemocytometers, etc) Decided to leave the original draft here. Please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:918512 for a proven design.

author: MDesigner423

title: Baptistery di San Giovanni: Florence, Italy

description.text:
The Baptistery of San Giovanni (or Saint John) is one of Florence's architectural masterpieces, a staple of Florentine cultural heritage, and a popular tourist destination.

This 3D printable mesh model of the ancient monument was constructed from a point cloud collected during laser scanning of the site as part of a diagnostic survey of the site my team and I conducted as part of our graduate school research. The model contains both the exterior and interior architectural features and can be cut open to reveal the chapel space and epic dome within. It took many days of persistent work to distill the 1.5 billion points at millimeter accuracy down to a 3D printable model that still captured the details of the monument, but we were finally able to finish it (and just in time!).

We initially built the model to help create a conservation plan for the site by looking at the history of the site's architectural progression and analyzing components that might be contributing to the site's structural degradation. Beyond that, we think that scientific data like this model should be shareable with everyone and not just hidden away for our academic pursuits.

Further details about our diagnostic cultural heritage engineering work in Florence and other sites and our efforts to create creative, open access art,and technology based on our research is posted on our site Open Access Antiquarianism. (http://openaccessantiquarianism.com/). You might want to especially check out this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TPjh4482K7Y) from the Center of Interdisciplinary Science for Art, Architecture, and Archaeology (CISA3) detailing results from two field seasons at the site.

title: New and Updated! Brick roller and Sand stamps

description.text:
Check out the all-new Sand Stamps!!!!

My goal for this challenge was not to make the most intricate castle that I could, but to make a better way to create an intricate and unique castle without spend your whole beach day doing it. 

                                 Brick Roller:  

       Ever get tired of having to draw brick into a sand castle one line at a time? Now with my Brick Roller, a whole sand castle can be "bricked" in seconds! This simple tool can save hours of drawing by simply rolling over the surface of a sand castle! To make the brick pattern, roll the Brick Roller across to make vertical lines and up to make horizontal lines. The result is a perfect and easy to do brick pattern.  

                                      Sand Stamps:  
      When you're at the beach, you don't want to spend hours on the hot sand trying carve difficult details into your sand castle. So why not speed up the process with Sand Stamps! Using the magnetic handle, you can quickly change stamps to imprint different designs to make your castle one of a kind! And now, for the first time ever, you can truly have the most unique castle on the beach with my colored hedge stamp! Since it is hollow, it can be filled with dyed water to create a colored pattern on your castle! To achieve this, simply cover the hedge pattern on the front of the stamp with gauze, fill with the dyed water, attach to the magnetic stamp handle, and press into the castle for a few seconds! The result? A beautifully colored castle.

Brick roller:

Print settings: First, in the defaults panel select Load Accelerated Defaults. Then manually change the infills and HBP temperatures for each model.The roller itself should be printed at 100% infill ONLY. Other wise the raised lines will snap very easily. The handle can be printed at a minimum of 20% infill. this model prints well with accelerated speeds. The HBP temperature should be set to 90 for both models.

Materials:
3/16" dowel pin
hot glue

Assembly: Place the roller in between the two prongs of the handle so that the holes aline. insert the dowel through the holes so that the roller can spin easily. If there is any resistance, sand the roller until no resistance occurs. Use hot glue to secure the ends of the dowel inside of the holes of the handle ONLY. Do not let any glue leak into the holes of the roller or it will not roll correctly.

Operation: To make the brick pattern, first cover the exterior of your castle with vertical lines by rolling the Brick Roller across the surface. Next, roll the Brick Roller up or down to create horizontal lines that intersect with the vertical ones. You should now have achieved your brick pattern. 

                                              Stamps:

Print settings: First, load accelerated defaults. Then manually change the infill to 60% for the stamp handle and 100% for the stamps. HBP temperature should be set at 105 degrees Celsius.

Materials:
Gauze pads (found at your local grocery store or pharmacy)
1/2 inch diameter 1/8 inch height round magnets found here:

http://www.walmart.com/ip/Craft-Hobby-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Super-Magnets-1-2-x-1-8-in.-12x3mm-6-Pieces/31029731

hot glue

Colored Stamps
Assembly: After all parts are printed, cut a piece of gauze so that it can fit in the bottom of the color stamp. Hot glue the edges of the gauze to the inside edge of the stamp. After glue has set, flip the stamp over so that you are looking at the pattern. Now, cut small strips of gauze and stuff them through the opening for the pattern. Stuff as much gauze as possible into the pattern and make sure that the gauze is level with the face of the stamp. Next, insert the stamp's bottom so that the hollow circle is facing the outside of the stamp. Seal in the edges around the bottom with hot glue. Now, it is time to insert the magnet. The most important part is that you install the magnet for the handle FIRST. Before you secure the magnet for the stamps, make sure the pole facing the outside of the stamp is opposite that of the handles. Other wise, you will have to redo the magnet, which is not easy. After the construction of the stamp is complete, you can fill the stamp with colored water either through the gauze over the pattern opening or through a hole in the side of the stamp*.

Operation: After filling with dyed water, gently shake the stamp to allow the gauze to soak in the color. then gently press stamp on sand.

  • If the stamp has a hole in the side of it, you will have to create a plug for it. You can do this by simply setting the stamp on its side, with the hole facing down, on a table. Fill hole with hot glue until it creates a bubble on top. Let hot glue set. When dry, peel stamp off of table and push out hot glue plug. rotate the plug 180 degrees along the Z axis and push back into hole.

title: Pirate Mickey with magnet, Fish Extenders

description.text:
This is a pirate mickey that I designed as a cabin gift for fish extenders. It has a pocket in the back to add in a magnet.
These models are set up for dual extrudes using black and red material, but I add a couple of cross braces between the swords to allow them to be made on a single extruder machine (have not tested, update!!! doesnt work well on single extruder, you need to cut the swords at the X and away from the head to allow assembly) I may re build for a single exturder if I find the time (really dont have any now...)
I will load the x3g files for a Prower spec 3d (flashforge creator)

comments.text: I'm about to put my deposit down on a cruise, and my GF told me about the extenders program.  This is certainly on my make it list.
comments.author: StorageJarett

comments.text:

We made 30 mickeys, 50 tinkerbells (with magnets to attach throughout the ship), (on board when the force awakens premiered) 20 Darth Vader rings, a death star ornament, mickey coaster set, and 2 sets of spiral ornaments. Im sure more I forgot.
Enjoy the cruise,

I like to print with ABS mainly because I can print complex objects or
sharp overhangs using HIPS as the support material. this does away with the worry of a huge tar clog if something went wrong like with
PVA allowing me to leave my printer unattended. However ABS smells terrible while printing so decided to make a filtration system out of an old CPAP machine my grandmother gave to me to fix. There will probably be some changes later on but for now this thing works wonders getting rid of almost all of the smell.

This fits perfectly in the replicator 2x and is held down with
command strips. no supports needed

1. print the parts (they are pretty self explanatory.)
  2. find some sort of fan to circulate air (mine was the CPAP machine model: REMstar pro C-Flex+)
  3. 6ft of 1/4" tubing cut into 2ft sections these will go on the suction
    side.
    4.Cut-to-Fit Carbon Pad for Air Purifiers by CFS (for primary
    filter from Amazon)
  4. 6 Foot 72" CPAP BIPAP FLEXIBLE AIR TUBING HOSE TUBE New Quality Sealed
  5. Hamilton Beach TrueAir Room Odor Eliminator ( for secondary
    filter)

No supports!!!!!!!

author: 3dprintsolutions

description.text:
OpenSCAD script that generates a 3D box of user-defined interior dimensions. The boxes have an interior throat which the lid sits on (hence the name). The length of that throat can be controlled, as can the general thickness of the sides.
I created this to make a small gift box.

Change the interior size dimensions. If your build platform is not large enough to print both top and bottom at the same time, you may need to separate them into separate objects, or comment out one and export the other.
I had to resort to two subs for thick and thin walls because of the way OpenSCAD works with regards to variables.  Thin walls are derived as a percentage of the shortest dimension of the box.  Thick walls are proportional to the dimension of the side they are on.  Thickness of the walls are defined by inner and outer sides variable - the throat is the inner side, and the outer side surrounds it.  Slop adds a little space to the inside of the lid so that it can fit - unless your 3D printer does perfectly smooth walls, you will probably need some slop, but you'll have to experiment to determine how much.
I plan to fix the annoyance with the variables and add a top|bottom|both switch to let you control which parts get rendered without having to comment out code, so I have set this to be a work in progress.

comments.text:
your use of the word 'parametric' is totally out of context !
There is nothing about your box that deserves to be labeled 'parametric' ;-(
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text: If you look at the OpenSCAD script, you will see a number of parameters that can be adjusted. This was normal use for the term 'parametric' five years ago when I designed and uploaded this thing.
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text:
The fact you can change parameters dos not make a model 'parametric'.
And by no means is 'OpenSCAD' any type of authority on verbiage.
Your model falls in the 'solid model' parameter.
comments.author: theron

comments.text: Speaking as an architect who works primarily in a BIM environment, that the model has alterable parameters makes it a parametric model as per our vernacular and accepted within the design community. That said there may be a more nuanced technical definition with a different set of requisites of which I am unaware, though I suspect our definition has more relevance here.
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text: So simple, so versatile. Easy to print. Thanks!
comments.author: byteborg

comments.text: Excellent!

description.text:
We've hit 500 downloads!

It's easy as one... two... three!

All you need to know:

The Easy as 1 2 3 Sand Castle and Mold is a castle and mold that were designed to be as EASY to use as possible. Unlike other mold designs you don't have to print a bunch of pieces to make one castle, this mold is one piece. Just one print and you're ready to have fun. (1) First, you download the mold, which is print ready. (2) Second, you print the mold, which is already scaled. (3) And third, you fill it with sand and place it down. If you don't feel like getting sand in your shorts or don't have a beach nearby you can print the castle by itself. (1) Download (2) Print (3) Play! To get a more in-depth explanation of my castle keep reading, otherwise you are ready to start printing and playing.

This is my entry for the #BuildACastle challenge. If you like it please support it with a like, collect, and comment!

Connection to mathematics:

While you read this you may wonder how my castle relates to math. As you probably know by now the number three appears a lot in this description and the reason for that is because the number three is used in so many different mathematical ways.

• In architecture every structural element is composed of a triangle, and a triangle has three corners and three sides. The reason why architects use triangles is because they are strong due to the fact that they distribute the weight effectively.

• Another way how the number three relates to mathematics is because it is the simplest shape. And simple is another way of saying EASY. An example of why it is the simplest shape is because a triangle has the least amount of sides that a shape, closed polygon, can have.

• And finally the THIRD and final way my castle is related to the number three and mathematics is because it's an .stl file. You may not know this but every surface in an .stl file is a triangle. This is so the program can read it easily, because a triangle is simple and EASY to comprehend.

Who am I:

Hi,
My name is Wyatt and I am 14 years old. I learned about 3D printers when I was 12 years old and immediately was interested. I started looking for printers online and the price of them crushed my dreams. I didn't give up and started researching the technology and science behind 3d printers and narrowed down what I wanted and what I didn't need. I found the SoliDoodle 2 Base and because it was only 499 at the time I was ready to tackle the complicity of the rugged printer. I asked for this printer on my 13th birthday, but I didn't get it... I got the SoliDoodle 2 Pro! Due to the fact that this printer was relatively inexpensive there had to be a lot of calibrating and fixing done. After half a year of trial and error due to printer malfunctions and software malfunction. I could print some pretty complex things such as the Cityscape and the Supreme Court Building. Then I was looking at YouTube and saw that you could print in wood! So I found the wood filament on amazon and ordered it. I tested it out in my printer and printed the MakerBot Gnome. It was so amazing I turned off my printer to show my family that I had printed wood! That was a big mistake because if you let the wood filament cool in your extruder it will get clogged. Long story short I had to take apart the extruder and drill and hole though the clogged part. Then I was back on track to being a maker. From then to now I have explored different design softwares and I did most of my designing in Sketchup make until I transitioned into junior high school where I took an exploring technology course and learned about Rhinoceros. At the time Rhino for mac was still in the WIP stage which meant I could get a $1000 dollar software for free! From then to now I've been using mostly Rhino for designing in 3D. My castle and mold were designed more than 90% in Rhino.

Motivation:

I was inspired to enter in this challenge because when I looked at all the current entries I saw that either the designs were flawed, it wasn't even a sand castle, you had to print multiple pieces to construct a mold, or the designs were being held back because they were trying too hard to relate to math. Instead of doing those things I made my files scaled, print ready, and support free. I also included a file of just my castle, not the mold, so if you don't like sand you can still have fun! My castle does not tessellate because tessellating holds back your imagination. However it is composed of geometrical shapes such as cylinders, quadrilateral pyramids, cones, rings, and even simple cubes. I made every element of this entry without any help. This castle should win the challenge because it relates to math, includes a castle and mold, is EASY to use, and it looks awesome.

Behind the scenes:

All elements of the castle and mold were created in free software’s. The castle and mold were mostly constructed in Rhino 5 (WIP which is why it was free). I also used Sketchup Make. Editing and finalizing was done in meshlab, netfabb basic, and Repetier for sizing. For the different photos of the castle I used rendering films in Rhino. For the colorful castle and diagram castle I used Photoshop Elements (free trial). I learned how to use all of these programs by Dan Sander's tech class, messing around with buttons, or YouTube.

Time-lapse of my castle and mold being printed

Special thanks to:

Brigitta Suwandana, Les Nielsen, and Dan Sander.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm for Castle, .3mm for Mold

Infill:

15%

The castle can be printed with these settings: I use 3 perimeters and an infill of at least 15%.

The mold can be printed with these settings: I use 3 perimeters and an infill of at least 20% with a honeycomb pattern.

Pros:
For the mold you don't have to worry about it breaking because it isn't thin. Unlike other designs it won't get jammed with pieces snapping together or rotating. And finally it doesn't matter if your printer is low quality because you won't be able to tell the quality once the sand is molded.

Cons:
...you tell me!

Made for a friend, replacement towers for the game The Kings Armory by Gate Keeper Games.

https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/145493/kings-armory

Two models attached, advanced has the little arch thingies on it and a different internal structure, The simple doesnt have the arches and has a simplified internal structure to reduce print time. The little arches are not really needed as they are hardly seen at the angle the game would have the towers at (on a table, looking down at them).

Sadly they do not fold, nor do they fit in the box! Give it a coat of white spray paint and then a thin watery black wash (mix black water paint and water) and you will end up with a simple stone look that works well.

description.text:
If you're a piper, you're familiar with the need to memorize every song you play. Now, you don't have to! Simply load your sheet music onto your smartphone (Samsung Galaxy S4 + Life Proof Case, ideally) and mount your phone to your blowpipe. This is still a work-in-progress. It works most of the time, but has a tendency to fall over/support portrait mode. Ensure that the mounting ring is tight before marching or any activity involving large movements.

1a. Download the model
1b. If needed, resize to fit your phone's specifications

  1. Place over the top of your blowpipe and slide down
  2. Play!

description.text:
Dopo aver completato il catenamento delle caverie mobili ecco quanto manca per realizzare la completa protezione delle componenti elettriche: la chiusura del sotto-piatto.
Le parti superiori sono previste amovibili e fissate con vitine M1x10, così che si possa manutenere facilmente la stampante, mentre il resto delle protezioni è da assemblare con la colla e fissare, sempre con colla, alla struttura in acrilico della stampante.

PS: l'ultimo componente di quest'oggetto, il #16, è assolutamente identico al primo componente del catenamento Y-Plate.

author: wardluk

description.text:
This accomplishes a number of things...
Pulls the filament off of the spools at a constant, low resistance around a gentle arc at a fixed position and angle.  Without it, filament pulls off the side of the spool at an extreme tight angle causing the spool to bounce around during reversal and Z movement.
You don't need spool housings around the spool to keep the filament in place.  Since it's being pulled off at a fixed angle, the filament no longer has a tendency to fall off the side and get tangled.  It also doesn't unwrap when Z homes, the tube rises instead and the spool remains wrapped nicely tight. (which gets really bad when you stack a second spool on top)
Makes switching between the 2 spools really easy since when you pull one out of the extruder, the tube holds the filament in place instead of spinning out of the spool and making a mess.
Provides another place to stash your tools!

Print out just the bottom part if you only have a single spool. Screw it into the other square slot on top of your ToM. If you have two spools stacked, print the top part and snap it together, no screws needed, slide it up and down to adjust the height. Note: you must use a tube to guide the filament around, otherwise it will twist around at a bad angle. A tube with an OD of about 6mm will press fit nicely into the small holes in the side. I suggest some PTFE tubing like this http://www.mcmaster.com/#52335k34 (note, that tube from McMaster might require you to make the holes in openscad slightly smaller) about 3 feet or so - it has to be long enough to form a nice gentle curve to reduce resistance. You could also try mounting it on the back left replacing the cap on top of the left Z rod. That might allow for a nicer curve through tubing...

title: Electrical Bolt Cover for Solderless Stepper Motor Mount

description.text:
Update 8/10/2015
I added a ledge to also cover the wire holes on belt side of the motor mount. This is designed to fit the remix version of the solderless motor mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:930862 , but might also fit the original version.

This is a cover plate to slip over the bolts that hold the wiring for the stepper motors on the solderless Stepper motor mount on the Mostly Printed CNC project. Mine came out to a nice snug fit.

Since this is an electrical connection, I wanted to cover these bolts & this seemed easy enough to design a cover for them. I included a file for 3/8" length screws, a file for 1/2" screws & an openscad file you can adjust to your configuration. I used 3/8" screws for my build.

I would print one to test fit before printing the other three or four that you will need.

comments.text: What is wrong with solder and heat shrink?
comments.author: johnbo

comments.text: Nothing, if that is what you want to use.
comments.author: johnbo

comments.text: Great idea! I was thinking those screws were just begging to be shorted out. If you could cover the inside as well, you would prevent any aluminum filings from getting lodged in there and killing your electrics. Maybe just a piece of electric tape will do the trick.

comments.text: Hey I have just assembled mine, just wondering, did you print this part with the cnc/3d printer or did you use something else? I'm just wondering how accurate it is at printing with fine tuning
comments.author: tmd1990

comments.text: I printed this with a Makerfarm 10" Prusa i3v.  It came out to a nice snug fig.  I used digital calipers to measure the distances & then multiplied by 1.05 for clearance & the fit came out perfect for me.
